Award.AwardTitle: Data-Driven Dynamic Reliability Assessment of Lithium-Ion Battery Considering Degradation Mechanisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to create a dynamic reliability assessment platform for lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery. Real-time diagnostics/prognostics and predictive maintenance/control of Li-ion battery are essential for reliable and safe battery operation in a wide-range of battery-powered applications, from hybrid and electric vehicles (HEVs/EVs) and medical devices, to the emerging smart grid and all electric airplanes. The proposed platform enables a battery management system (BMS) to develop predictive maintenance/control of a Li-ion battery through concurrently analyzing degradation mechanisms and anticipating failure modes. Successful execution of this research will advance our understanding of how to extend life and prevent catastrophic failure of Li-ion batteries, and will potentially lead to development of battery-powered devices that are more durable and safer than current devices. This project will disseminate research findings to battery industry by demonstrating the platform with a Li-ion battery in an implantable application, through collaboration with a leading industry partner. The project will offer a wide range of education and outreach programs, including 1) incorporating research findings into the Reliability Engineering curriculum, 2) leveraging university research programs to attract undergraduate and K-12 students to engineering career, and 3) organizing paper sessions and panels on Design for Failure Prevention of Li-Ion Battery in major conferences.

To date, real-time diagnostics/prognostics of Li-ion battery has been exploited only empirically and largely in isolation with the underlying degradation mechanisms. This may be attributed to the lack of cognizance of the causal relationship between degradation mechanisms and failure modes. This project will bridge the gap between physical mechanisms and functional failures by creating a dynamic reliability assessment platform that facilitates a synergistic integration of physics-based modeling and sensor-based prognostics. The platform will allow for: 1) identification and quantitative analysis of multiple degradation mechanisms through online estimation of the degradation parameters; and 2) anticipation of the failure modes through online prediction of their remaining useful lives (RULs). The creation of the platform involves three research thrusts: 1) validation of multiphysics models, which updates multiphysics battery models using high precision charge-discharge cycling data; 2) training of health estimators, which adopts machine learning to quantitatively analyze multiple degradation mechanisms from a single measurement of charge curve; and 3) prognostics of failure modes, which leverages the quantitative degradation analysis for prediction of failure mode RULs. The platform provides the methods and tools needed to leverage prognostics and prognostics-informed predictive maintenance/control for achieving the failure prevention capability of BMS. Although this project focuses on the specific case of dynamically updating battery reliability with measured electrical data, the methodology will be applicable to other engineering cases in which measured data are used to dynamically update reliability estimates that support maintenance/control decision making.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to create a dynamic reliability assessment platform for lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries. Real-time diagnostics/prognostics and predictive maintenance/control of Li-ion batteries are essential for reliable and safe battery operation in a wide-range of battery-powered applications, from hybrid and electric vehicles and medical devices, to the emerging smart grid and all electric airplanes. The platform will enable battery management system (BMS) to develop predictive maintenance/control of Li-ion battery cells by analyzing degradation mechanisms and anticipating failure modes. Our creation of the reliability assessment platform at Iowa State University consisted of three research thrusts: 1) validating multiphysics battery models using high precision charge/discharge cycling data; 2) training health estimators to analyze multiple degradation mechanisms from a single measurement of charge curve; and 3) building life predictors to predict the remaining useful life (RUL).

 

This project has produced the following key results.

- We developed a physics-informed diagnostics approach that automates the process of probing the degradation mechanisms of lithium-ion battery cells based on readily available measurements of cell voltage and current. One unique property of this approach is that it employs a deep learning model that learns from a simple, largely imperfect physics-based model.

- We created a physics-based prognostics approach that performs RUL prediction with consideration of multiple concurrent degradation mechanisms. This approach can give more accurate and physically more meaningful predictions than traditional capacity-based prognostics approaches.

- We experimentally validated the diagnostics and prognostics approaches by acquiring a high-precision cycling dataset from 24 implantable-grade lithium-ion cells over a 1.5-year test duration. The cycling tests are still ongoing as of November 1st, 2020 and have produced more than 2.5 years of high-precision cycling data.

- We developed a new system reliability analysis method that was shown to improve the computational efficiency over current state-of-the-art. This improvement was achieved via a novel extension of Gaussian process regression, a probabilistic machine learning technique, to a hybrid metamodeling framework. Such an extension contributes to the science of engineering design by being the first study that investigates the use of hybrid Gaussian process metamodeling to enable efficient system reliability analysis.

 

Broad impacts of the project are the following. (i) The physics-informed diagnostics approach represents an important step towards online quantitative analysis of degradation mechanisms which is a notoriously challenging task. (ii) The physics-based prognostics approach has the potential to increase the practical adoption of failure prognostics in battery design (offline) and BMS (online) applications. This increased adoption will contribute to enhancing the durability and safety of current and next-generation battery-powered devices. (iii) The system reliability analysis method can reduce the design cycle time of engineered systems, potentially broadening the application of engineering design under uncertainty to complex systems. (iv) Engaging five undergraduate students and five Ph.D. students in research helped them gain knowledge and experience in a wide range of areas including BMS, signal processing, machine learning, and failure prognostics. (v) The topics of battery capacity estimation and RUL prediction were integrated into the content of a new graduate-level course, thereby improving the reliability engineering curriculum of the College of Engineering at Iowa State University. (vi) The results of this project were actively shared with other researchers and industry partners through conference presentations and invited discussions.


Last Modified: 11/11/2020
Modified by: Chao Hu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The objective of this project is to create a dynamic reliability assessment platform for lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries. Real-time diagnostics/prognostics and predictive maintenance/control of Li-ion batteries are essential for reliable and safe battery operation in a wide-range of battery-powered applications, from hybrid and electric vehicles and medical devices, to the emerging smart grid and all electric airplanes. The platform will enable battery management system (BMS) to develop predictive maintenance/control of Li-ion battery cells by analyzing degradation mechanisms and anticipating failure modes. Our creation of the reliability assessment platform at Iowa State University consisted of three research thrusts: 1) validating multiphysics battery models using high precision charge/discharge cycling data; 2) training health estimators to analyze multiple degradation mechanisms from a single measurement of charge curve; and 3) building life predictors to predict the remaining useful life (RUL). This project has produced the following key results. - We developed a physics-informed diagnostics approach that automates the process of probing the degradation mechanisms of lithium-ion battery cells based on readily available measurements of cell voltage and current. One unique property of this approach is that it employs a deep learning model that learns from a simple, largely imperfect physics-based model. - We created a physics-based prognostics approach that performs RUL prediction with consideration of multiple concurrent degradation mechanisms. This approach can give more accurate and physically more meaningful predictions than traditional capacity-based prognostics approaches. - We experimentally validated the diagnostics and prognostics approaches by acquiring a high-precision cycling dataset from 24 implantable-grade lithium-ion cells over a 1.5-year test duration. The cycling tests are still ongoing as of November 1st, 2020 and have produced more than 2.5 years of high-precision cycling data. - We developed a new system reliability analysis method that was shown to improve the computational efficiency over current state-of-the-art. This improvement was achieved via a novel extension of Gaussian process regression, a probabilistic machine learning technique, to a hybrid metamodeling framework. Such an extension contributes to the science of engineering design by being the first study that investigates the use of hybrid Gaussian process metamodeling to enable efficient system reliability analysis. Broad impacts of the project are the following. (i) The physics-informed diagnostics approach represents an important step towards online quantitative analysis of degradation mechanisms which is a notoriously challenging task. (ii) The physics-based prognostics approach has the potential to increase the practical adoption of failure prognostics in battery design (offline) and BMS (online) applications. This increased adoption will contribute to enhancing the durability and safety of current and next-generation battery-powered devices. (iii) The system reliability analysis method can reduce the design cycle time of engineered systems, potentially broadening the application of engineering design under uncertainty to complex systems. (iv) Engaging five undergraduate students and five Ph.D. students in research helped them gain knowledge and experience in a wide range of areas including BMS, signal processing, machine learning, and failure prognostics. (v) The topics of battery capacity estimation and RUL prediction were integrated into the content of a new graduate-level course, thereby improving the reliability engineering curriculum of the College of Engineering at Iowa State University. (vi) The results of this project were actively shared with other researchers and industry partners through conference presentations and invited discussions.
